items.title: Add missing tests
items.body:
There are a bunch of query terms that don't have tests. If you're looking to help contribute to the driver, adding tests for some of these would be a great help.

- [ ] index-status
- [ ] index-wait
- [ ] inner-join
- [ ] outer-join
- [ ] eq-join
- [ ] zip
- [ ] with-fields
- [ ] concat-map
- [ ] skip
- [ ] limit
- [ ] slice
- [ ] nth
- [ ] indexes-of
- [ ] is-empty
- [ ] union
- [ ] sample
- [ ] group
- [ ] ungroup
- [ ] reduce
- [ ] count
- [ ] contains
- [ ] pluck
- [ ] append
- [ ] prepend
- [ ] difference
- [ ] set-insert
- [ ] set-union
- [ ] set-intersection
- [ ] set-difference
- [ ] has-fields
- [ ] insert-at
- [ ] splice-at
- [ ] delete-at
- [ ] change-at
- [x] keys
- [x] values
- [ ] literal
- [x] object
- [ ] sub
- [ ] mul
- [ ] div
- [ ] mod
- [ ] not
- [ ] now
- [ ] for-each
- [ ] http
- [ ] desc
- [ ] to-geojson
- [ ] get-intersection
- [ ] get-nearest
- [ ] includes
- [ ] intersects
- [ ] polygon
- [ ] polygon-sub
- [x] rebalance

items.title: Support 2.2's conn.server command
items.body:
> We’ve also added a way for clients to determine which RethinkDB server they’re connected to. You can call conn.server to get the server information on a connection.

https://github.com/rethinkdb/rethinkdb/issues/3934

From the driver mailing list:

> We’ve added support for a new QueryType SERVER_INFO. When this
query is sent to the server, the server will respond with a
Response that has the corresponding SERVER_INFO ResponseType,
and the same format as a SUCCESS_ATOM response. The official
drivers expose this as a function server() on the connection
object (so you write c = r.connect(...); c.server() to retrieve
the information).

items.title: Support 2.2's value command
items.body:
> In RethinkDB 2.2 we added a new values command that mirrors the existing keys command and allows getting field values from an object:

```
// Returns `[1, 2]`
r.expr({ a: 1, b: 2}).values()
```

items.title: Update to support 2.2's name base UUID
items.body:
https://github.com/rethinkdb/rethinkdb/pull/4636

> Peter Hollows expanded the r.uuid command to support name-based UUIDs using SHA1. You can now call r.uuid(name) in ReQL to get a name-based UUID.

items.title: Mask auth-key when logging connection exceptions
items.body: We don't want the auth-key to be leaked into logs as this may expose it to non-secure non-production environments. Whenever any errors are logged with the connection, the auth-key should be masked.

items.title: Non-markdown folders produce empty list elements
items.body: They are 'null' values in the json file.

items.title: Exclude `uuid` in :refer-clojure for rethinkdb.query
items.body:
A new 1.7 version of ClojureScript contains `uuid`, which we are now shadowing. It needs to be excluded to avoid these warnings:

```
WARNING: uuid already refers to: cljs.core/uuid being replaced by: rethinkdb.query/uuid at line 790 file:/Users/Daniel/.m2/repository/rethinkdb/rethinkdb/0.11.0-SNAPSHOT/rethinkdb-0.11.0-SNAPSHOT.jar!/rethinkdb/query.cljc
```

items.title: Update time arity to only support 4 and 7 args
Support creating simple indexes
items.body:
http://rethinkdb.com/api/javascript/index_create/

> Command syntax
>```
table.indexCreate(indexName[, indexFunction][, {multi: false, geo: false}]) → object
```
> ...
> * Simple indexes based on the value of a single field.
> ...

It doesn't look like our index-create supports creating simple indexes, it requires `table`, `index-name`, and `func`. I think this will just need a new arity added, or making `func` optional.

items.title: Add support for new RethinkDB terms
items.body:
There are a few query terms we need to add to stay up to parity with the official RethinkDB drivers. I've seen `row` and `expr`, but there may be more as well. We need to 

- [ ] check and compare the [http://rethinkdb.com/api/javascript/](docs) and find out what's missing.
- [ ] Add the missing items.

items.title: Screenshots
items.body: There should be some screenshots or a live instance somewhere just to show how the app looks like.

items.title: Add support for new ReQL terms
items.body:
New ReQL terms are [available](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rethinkdb-dev/6GeJW-srWAg). This should be pretty easy to add support for them.

> New ReQL Terms

> ceil — takes a number and rounds it to integer above it.
> floor — takes a number and rounds it to the integer below it.
> round — takes a number and rounds it to the nearest integer.

items.title: rethinkdb.query/changes argument name shouldn't be `table`
items.body: `rethinkdb.query/changes` can be called on lots of things, not just a table, so the argument name should be something different. Probably `xs` as that's a common idiom in Clojure to represent a sequence.

items.title: Speeding up tests
items.body:
Currently the testing code checks for existence of a table, then drops it if it exists, then creates a new one. It would be much faster if we generated tables with different UUID's, and each test was assigned one of them for use.

There's two ways this could work:

1. In the `setup-each` function, create a new table with a UUID name, and bind it to a var to be used by the test. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31735423/how-to-pass-a-value-from-a-fixture-to-a-test-with-clojure-test/31736107#31736107 looks helpful for this.
2. A faster way to do this might be to generate all the tables up front, and dish one out to each test as it started running. I'm not sure whether this would be meaningfully faster, or worth the complexity.

This could be a good PR for someone who wants to get their toes wet in the codebase.

items.title: Switch to Cheshire for JSON
items.body: Cheshire is much faster and better supported than clojure.data.json, it would be good to move to it.

items.title: Turn query vector into query map
items.body:
To avoid more bugs like #52 it could be good to turn the query vector into a query map. It could look something like: 

```clj
{:token 5
 :query ...
 :json-query ... ; turned into raw JSON arrays
 :query-type
 :global-optargs}
```

This would make it easier to put assertions in various places to ensure that queries are being constructed correctly.
